Because the root mean square of the voltage counts and that is lower for DC

answers.answer_text: Because with AC, arcs in the fuse are extinguished at the first zero-crossing of the AC waveform
Because DC voltage is more dangerous and requires more insulation
Because of the non-alternating current, DC current exerts one-sided strain on the fuse

text:
The following electric circuit may be used to convert an input voltage to a different output voltage to supply a load ("switched mode power supply"). The input voltage is 12V, the load draws a constant current of 2A (independent of the output voltage).
The MOSFET is turned on and turned off periodically, according to a pulse width modulated (PWM) control signal. The switching frequency is 250kHz. The duty cycle (ratio of the turn on time of the MOSFET to period time) is used to control the output voltage. The switching losses of the MOSFET are neglectable. In turned on condition, the MOSFET can be assumed to have constant resistance drain to source (Rdson). The diode can be assumed to be ideal (zero forward voltage, zero switching losses, zero reverse recovery, ...). The inductor is formed by windings on a ferromagnetic core. The core reaches saturation at current values higher than those occurring during normal operation. All voltages are referenced to ground ("GND").
Which of the following statements about the circuit is true? There is only one correct statement!

answer_options.answer_text: In steady-state operation, the circuit can only provide output voltages (v_out) that are higher than the input voltage (12V).

In case of output short circuit, the magnetic flux in the ferromagnetic core of the inductor reaches its saturation value. This leads to intrinsic limitation of the output current (i_out) in case of output short circuit.
The power dissipation of the circuit is given by Pdissipation = |12V - v_out| · i_out.
When decreasing the output voltage (v_out) at constant output current (i_out), the power losses due to the Rdson of the MOSFET increase.
When increasing the output voltage (v_out) at constant output current (i_out), the power losses due to the Rdson of the MOSFET increase.

answers.answer_text: In steady-state operation, the circuit can only provide output voltages (v_out) that are higher than the input voltage (12V).

In case of output short circuit, the magnetic flux in the ferromagnetic core of the inductor reaches its saturation value. This leads to intrinsic limitation of the output current (i_out) in case of output short circuit.
The power dissipation of the circuit is given by Pdissipation = |12V - v_out| · i_out.
When decreasing the output voltage (v_out) at constant output current (i_out), the power losses due to the Rdson of the MOSFET increase.
When increasing the output voltage (v_out) at constant output current (i_out), the power losses due to the Rdson of the MOSFET increase.

The figure below depicts an Improved Howland Current Pump circuit. Assume that Vin- is connected to ground, 0 V, and Vin  is 5 V. For R1 = R2 = R3 = 1 kΩ and R4 = 100 Ω, compute the magnitude of the output current Iout.\n Answer in mA and provide the value with 1 decimal place, e.g. 12.3.

solutions.text:
Formulas for an improved howland pump circuit:\n
Iout = (G × (Vin + − Vin −))/R4,\n
G = R3/R1; R3/R1 = (R5 + R4)/R3\n
G = 1k/1k = 1; 1 = (R5 + R4)/R3 <=> R5 = 1000 − 100 = 900 Ω\n
Iout = 1 * (5 − 0)/100 = 0. 05 A = 50. 0 mA

text: This year you want to double your accumulator voltage to match your new high voltage electrical motor. Assume you keep the same accumulator nominal energy and the same cells you used last year and change only the cell configuration (series/parallel). Complete the statement: For the same power profile at the battery output, the power dissipated in the new accumulator internal resistance is (………) the previous accumulator.

solutions.text:
Cells - Ecell (cell nominal energy), Vcell (cell nominal voltage), Rcell (cell internal resistance)\n
Battery old - Eold (old battery nominal energy), Vold (old battery total nominal voltage),\n
Rold (old battery total internal resistance), (Sold)s(Pold)p (old battery series parallel configuration), Presold (old battery dissipated power in internal resistance)\n
Battery new - Enew (new battery nominal energy), Vnew (new battery total nominal voltage),\n
Rnew (new battery total internal resistance), (Snew)s(Pnew)p (new battery series parallel configuration), Presnew (new battery dissipated power in internal resistance)\n
Power profile - Ppro (RMS power), Ipro (RMS current)\n
We want Vnew = 2*Vold => Snew = 2*Sold (eqA)\n
To keep Enew = Eold => Sold * Pold = Snew * Pnew (eqB)\n
From A and B we get Pnew = Pold/2 (eqC)\n
Rold = Rcell * Sold / Pold (eqD)\n
Rnew = Rcell * Snew / Pnew (eqE)\n
From A, B and E we get Rnew = Rcell * 2*Sold / (Pod/2) = Rcel * 4 * Sold/Pold => Rnew = 4*Rold\n
Ipro = Ppro / Vbat\n
Iproold = Ppro / Vold\n
Ipronew = Ppro / Vnew = Ppro / (2*Vold) => Ipronew = ½ * Iproold\n
Pres = Rbat * Ipro^2\n
Presold = Rold * Iproold\n
Presnew = Rnew * Ipronew = 4*Rold * (½ * Iprold)^2 =>\n
=> Presnew = Presold

text:
You have a powertrain composed of a battery with an internal resistance of 0.2 Ω and an OCV (Open Circuit Voltage) of 500V, an inverter with an efficiency of 97%, a single electric motor with an efficiency of 94%, a chain transmission with a gear ratio of 4 (reduction of motor speed) and an efficiency of 98% and a differential with a gear ratio of 1 and an efficiency of 96%. The vehicle is two wheel drive with a wheel radius of 0.3 m.Consider no other losses.
 At a given moment, during braking with energy recovery, the current entering the battery is 84 A and the vehicle speed is 70 km/h.
 At that moment, how much torque is being produced by each wheel? 
Answer in Nm and provide the value with 0 decimal places, e.g. 12.

solutions.text:
Vbat=OCV+I*R = 500 + 84*0.2 = 516.8 V \n
Pbat=I*Vbat = 43 411,2 W \n
Pground = Pbat/(product of efficiencies) = 43 411,2 / (0.97*0.94*0.98*0.96) = 50 606,3 W \n
Speed = 70 km/h = 70000/3600 = 19.444 m/s \n
⍵ = speed / perimeter * 2π = 19.444 / (2 * 0.3 * π) * 2π = 64,814 rad/s \n
Pwheel = ⍵*τ = Pground/2 \n
τ = Pwheel/⍵ = 50 606,3 / 2 / 64,814 = 390 Nm

Assumption:
- Battery cells are closely packed without separation into modules.
- Commutation is resolved and has no losses.
- Although it is not the same depending on the configuration, positive and negative busses of the battery and the wires connecting to the motor are assumed to have irrelevant losses for simplicity.
- Battery and motor operating voltage will match.
- Inductance.

While ignoring battery main positive and negative buses and short wire from buses to the motor windings, do you go for:

answer_options.answer_text: Fully utilizing winding space with more turns of thinner wire because it will result in higher operating voltage of the motor, thus less current for the same power meaning less losses and better efficiency. Battery current will also be lesser leading to less heating.
Wire thickness in motor and battery configuration don't impact efficiency and power if winding space is fully utilized and battery connections are as short as possible.
Fully utilizing winding space with less turns off thicker wire as it will be able to pass more current so more power will be produced, plus motor will spin faster for the same voltage.
